questions.text: Which of the following statements best explains the purpose of planning?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The purpose of planning is to ensure optimal use of limited resources, avoiding wasteful expenditure, and formulating the best course of action to achieve defined objectives.

Hence, all of the above is correct.

Health Planning

  • Ensures economic utilisation of material, manpower, and financial resources. (Option A)
  • Purpose: to meet the health needs and demands of people.
  • Health Needs:
    • Defined as deficiencies in health requiring preventive, curative, control, or eradication measures.
    • Examples of community health needs: Medical care, safe water supply, adequate nutrition, immunisation, and family planning.
  • Resources in Health Planning:
    • Resources imply manpower, money, materials, skills, knowledge, techniques, and time.
    • Needed for the performance and support of planned actions.
    • Without proper planning and management → resources can be wasted. (Option B)
  • Objective:
    • A precise, planned endpoint of activities. (Option C)
    • Either achieved or not achieved.
  • Target:
    • Refers to discrete activities(e.g., number of blood films collected, vasectomies done).
    • Allows measuring the degree of achievement.
    • Concerned with the factors of a problem.
  • Goal:
    • The ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed.
    • Not limited by time, resources, or feasibility.

questions.text:
The Planning cycle has several steps. Which of the following sequences is correct?
A: Monitoring and Evaluation
B: Programming and Implementation
C: Assessment of resources
D: Analysis of existing health situation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct sequence is DCBA, following the logical progression of steps in the planning cycle:

Analysis of existing health situation (D):

  • Involves assessing current health status, identifying health problems, determining their causes, and understanding factors influencing health outcomes.
  • Provides the foundation for planningby highlighting priority areas needing attention.

Assessment of resources (C):

  • After understanding the health situation, assess available resources such as personnel, facilities, finances, and equipment.
  • Helps determine the capacity and constraints for addressing identified health issues.

Programming and Implementation (B):

  • Based on the health situation analysis and resource assessment, programs and interventions are planned and developed.
  • Involves designing strategies, setting objectives, defining activities, and establishing timelines for implementation.

Monitoring and Evaluation (A):

  • Once programs are implemented, it is essential to monitor progress and evaluate effectiveness.
  • Monitoring tracks the implementation process, while evaluation assesses the impact and outcomes.
  • Helps identify successes, challenges, and areas for improvement, informing future planning cycles.

Hence, the correct sequence is DCBA, as it follows the logical order of steps in the planning cycle. Other options do not follow this progression.

questions.text: A public health officer is planning to implement a new vaccination program in a rural district. Before proceeding, she wants to evaluate whether the expected economic gains-such as reduced treatment costs and increased productivity-justify the investment in the program. Which evaluation method should she use to compare the program's economic benefits with its costs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is cost-benefit analysis.

Cost-benefit analysis:

  • A method used to compare the economic benefits of a program or project with the costs incurred.
  • Involves quantifying both benefits and costs in monetary terms and comparing them to determine whether benefits outweigh costs.
  • Helps decision-makers evaluate the efficiency and feasibility of implementing a program by considering its potential economic returns.
  • It directly relates to comparing economic benefits with incurred costs, which is the essence of cost-benefit analysis.
  • The other options focus on different methods or purposes in economic evaluation and analysis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cost-effective analysis (Option B):

  • Compares relative costs and outcomes of different interventions.
  • Focuses on identifying the most efficient way to achieve a specific outcome by comparing the cost per unit of outcome.
  • Does not consider broader economic benefits, unlike cost-benefit analysis.

Cost accounting (Option C):

  • Involves recording, classifying, and analysing costs within an organisation.
  • Primarily for internal management, cost control, and resource optimisation.
  • Does not compare costs with external economic benefits.

Network analysis (Option D):

  • Analyses complex systems of interconnected elements(e.g., transportation, communication, project management networks).
  • Uses techniques like CPM and PERT to optimise activity or resource flow.
  • Not focused on comparing costs and benefits.

questions.text: The most comprehensive indicator of cost-effectiveness analysis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

QALYs gained provide a comprehensive measure of the impact of interventions on an individual's health-related quality of life, considering both longevity and well-being.

QALYs gained:

  • Quality-adjusted life years (QALYs)combine both the quantity and quality of life gained from an intervention into a single measure.
  • Accounts for changes in health-related quality of life by weighting each year of life gained by a utility value, representing the individual's health status.
  • Enables decision-makers to compare the cost-effectiveness of interventions across different health conditions and outcomes, taking into account both length and quality of life.

Explanation of Other Options:

No. of life years gained (Option A):

  • Focuses solely on the quantity of life gained, without considering the quality of life experienced by individuals.
  • Important outcome measure, but not comprehensive.

No. of heart attacks avoided (Option B):

  • Specific to a particular health outcome(heart attacks).
  • Does not account for overall health-related quality of life or other health conditions and outcomes.

Cost per life year gained (Option D):

  • Measures cost-effectiveness in terms of extending life expectancy.
  • Does not account for the quality of life experienced during the additional years.

questions.text: Which of the following is a set point framed for long-term plans but is something that cannot be quantified or measured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Goals represent a broad, qualitative aspiration that guides long-term planning efforts and cannot be easily quantified or measured like targets or objectives.

  • These represent overarching aspirations or desired outcomes that provide direction and purpose for long-term planning.
  • Unlike targets, goals are broader in scope and may encompass a range of objectives and targets within them.
  • Goals often express qualitative or abstract aims that cannot be easily quantified or measured
  • Examples: Improving community health and well-being, promoting social justice, and enhancing environmental sustainability.
  • Goals provide a vision or destination, guiding the development of more specific objectives and targets to achieve them.

Explanation of Other Options:

Target (Option A):

  • A specific, measurable value or achievement that serves as a milestone toward reaching a goal.
  • Quantifiable and measurable, often expressed as numerical values or percentages.
  • Example: Reducing child mortality rates by 25% over five years.

Objective (Option C):

  • A specific and measurable step or action that contributes to achieving a goal.
  • Quantifiable and tangible, providing clear direction for action.
  • Often expressed using SMART criteria(Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound).
  • Example: Increasing vaccination coverage by 10% within one year.

Mission (Option D):

  • Defines the overall purpose, values, and identity of an organisation or project.
  • Articulates the fundamental reason for existence and broader aspirations.
  • Provides a guiding framework for decision-making and goal-setting, but is not specific or measurable.

questions.text: Time taken for any project is estimated by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Network analysis is the most appropriate choice for estimating project duration, as network analysis methods like CPM and PERT are specifically designed for this purpose.

Network Analysis:

  • Techniques like Critical Path Method (CPM)and Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)are commonly used to estimate the time required for completing a project.
  • Involves creating a visual representation of the project's activities and their dependencies.
  • Identifies the critical path(the longest path through the project network) and estimates the duration of each activity.
  • By analysing the network diagram, project managers can determine the overall project duration and identify tasks critical to project completion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Work Sampling (Option A):

  • Technique to study the activities of workers or systemsby taking random samples at predetermined intervals.
  • Used to analyse work patterns, identify areas of improvement, and determine resource allocation.
  • Not designed for estimating total project time.

Input-Output Analysis (Option B):

  • Economic technique studying interdependencies between sectors or inputs and outputs within a system.
  • Quantifies relationships between resources, materials, labour (inputs) and goods/services (outputs).
  • Provides insights into resource allocation and efficiency, but is not used for project duration estimation.

Systems Analysis (Option D):

  • Problem-solving technique to study complex systems and identify improvement opportunities.
  • May involve analysing time-related aspects, such as workflow or resource utilisation.
  • Not specifically focused on estimating project duration like CPM and PERT.

questions.text: All are elements of evaluation except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While repeatability is important in scientific research, it is not a core element of evaluation like relevance, acceptability, and effectiveness. Hence, option A is correct.

Repeatability:

  • Refers to the ability to reproduce or repeat results consistently under the same conditions.
  • While desirable in scientific experiments and measurements, it is not typically considered an element of evaluation in the context of assessing programs or projects.

Explanation of Other Options:

Relevance (Option B):

  • Focuses on the extent to which the evaluation questions, methods, and findings are pertinent and applicable to the objectives and context of the program or project.
  • Evaluations should address relevant questions and provide meaningful insights for stakeholders.

Acceptability (Option C):

  • Involves considering the perceptions and opinions of stakeholders regarding the evaluation process and findings.
  • Ensures that evaluation results are credible, trusted, and actionable.
  • Includes program beneficiaries, implementers, funders, and other relevant parties.

Effectiveness (Option D):

  • Refers to the degree to which a program or intervention achieves its intended outcomes and goals.
  • Evaluations assess effectiveness by examining whether desired outcomes are achieved and the intervention produces the intended impact.
  • Fundamental for understanding program success or failure and informing future decision-making.

questions.text: Which of the following explains how well the sources are utilised?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Efficiency specifically addresses the utilisation of resources to achieve outcomes, making it the most appropriate option among the given choices.

Efficiency:

  • Refers to how well resources(such as time, money, and effort) are utilised to achieve a specific level of output or outcome.
  • Focuses on the relationship between inputs and outputs, assessing whether resources are being used optimally to produce desired results.
  • In evaluation, efficiency helps stakeholders understand whether a program or intervention is cost-effectively achieving its goals.

Explanation of Other Options:

Effectiveness (Option B):

  • Refers to the extent to which a program or intervention achieves its intended outcomes and goals.
  • Assesses success in achieving outcomes, but does not measure how efficiently resources are used.

Impact (Option C):

  • Refers to broader and long-term effects or consequences of a program beyond immediate outcomes.
  • Assesses the overall effects on individuals, communities, or systems, including intended and unintended outcomes.
  • Does not directly measure resource utilisation.

Adequacy (Option D):

  • Refers to whether resources allocated to a program are sufficient to meet needs or objectives.
  • Focuses on whether resources are enough to support activities and achieve outcomes.
  • Does not specifically assess how efficiently resources are used.

questions.text: Analysis done for expenditure of a large proportion for a small number and vice versa is called:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ABC analysis is the most appropriate choice as it specifically addresses the analysis of expenditure proportions for items based on their significance and usage frequency.

ABC Analysis:

  • Also known as Activity-Based Costing, it is used for analysing and categorising items based on their significance in terms of expenditure.
  • Involves classifying items based on relative cost importance:
    1. Category A:High value but low frequency of usage.
    2. Category C:Low value but high frequency of usage.
  • Helps in prioritising resources and efforts where they are most needed, maximising efficiency and cost-effectiveness.

Explanation of Other Options:

SDE (Option B):

  • Stands for Scarce, Difficult, and Easy
  • Used in inventory management to classify items based on availability and procurement difficulty.
  • Not directly related to analysing expenditure proportions.

VED (Option C):

  • Stands for Vital, Essential, and Desirable
  • Classifies items based on criticality for production or operation.
  • Helps prioritise inventory management, but does not focus on expenditure proportions.

FSN (Option D):

  • Stands for Fast-moving, Slow-moving, and Non-moving
  • Classifies inventory based on the rate of consumption or movement.
  • Useful for inventory optimisation but not for analysing expenditure proportions.

questions.text: In the management of stores, VED, D stands for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is Desirable

VED Analysis: A method used in store management to categorise inventory items based on their criticality for production or operation.

Each letter in VED stands for:

  1. V:Vital
  2. E:Essential
  3. D:Desirable

Desirable:

  • Refers to items that are not crucial for immediate operations but may have some importance or utility.
  • Less critical than vital items, but still considered necessary to have in inventory.

Explanation of Other Options:

Discrete (Option A): Refers to something separate or distinct, not related to VED analysis or inventory management.

Decide (Option C): A verb meaning to make a decision, unrelated to VED analysis.

Definite (Option D): Means clear, certain, or fixed, and does not correspond to any category in VED analysis.

questions.text: In primary health care, ABC and VED are related to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Drug inventory management at PHC is the most appropriate choice as it accurately reflects the application of ABC and VED analysis in the context of primary healthcare drug inventory management.

ABC and VED analysis:

  • Inventory management techniques are commonly used in healthcare facilities, including primary health centres (PHCs).
  • Help classify and manage medical supplies and drugs efficiently, ensuring optimal resource utilisation.

Explanation of Other Options:

National program evaluation at PHC level (Option A):

  • ABC and VED analyses are not directly related to national program evaluations.
  • Focus is on managing inventory, not evaluating program effectiveness.

Staff management at PHC (Option C):

  • ABC and VED analyses are not used for personnel management.
  • Specifically designed for inventory control.

Vaccination coverage assessment in PHC area (Option D):

  • Although vaccination coverage is important in PHC operations, ABC and VED analysis do not directly relate to this activity.
  • Primarily used for managing drug inventories and ensuring the availability of essential medications.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques can be used for inventory control in a large multispecialty hospital?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All mentioned techniques (ABC analysis, VED analysis, SDE analysis, and FSN analysis) can be used for inventory control in a large multispecialty hospital.

ABC Analysis (Option A): Categorises items based on value and contribution to overall costs:

  • A:High-value items
  • B:Medium-value items
  • C:Low-value items

Helps prioritise resources and manage high-value items effectively.

VED Analysis (Option B): Categorises items based on criticality and necessity:

  • V:Vital
  • E:Essential
  • D:Desirable

Aids in identifying and prioritising critical items essential for patient care and hospital operations.

SDE Analysis (Option C): Stands for Scarce, Difficult, and Easy.

  • Categorises items based on availability and procurement challenges.
  • Focuses on items that are scarce or difficult to procure, ensuring adequate stock levels.

FSN Analysis: Categorises items based on consumption rates:

  • F:Fast-moving
  • S:Slow-moving
  • N:Non-moving

Helps in managing stock levels and reducing the risk of stockouts or excess inventory.

questions.text: Quality assessment for health-related programs. What type of evaluation does clinical management in a health service belong to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Process evaluation is the most appropriate method for assessing clinical management in a health service as it focuses on the implementation and delivery of healthcare processes, which are crucial for ensuring high-quality patient care and effective service delivery.

Process Evaluation:

  • Clinical management primarily pertains to the processes involved in delivering healthcare services, including diagnosis, treatment, and patient care.
  • Evaluating clinical management focuses on how healthcare services are implemented, rather than just the results, making it part of process evaluation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Output Evaluation (Option A):

  • Focuses on tangible results or outcomes of a program or intervention.
  • While clinical management affects patient outcomes (e.g., improved health, reduced mortality), output evaluation measures results, not the process of care itself.

Input Evaluation (Option B):

  • Assesses resources and inputs allocated to a program (e.g., staffing, equipment, funding).
  • Evaluating inputs alone does not provide insight into the quality or effectivenessof clinical processes.

Impact Evaluation (Option D):

  • Assesses the broader effects or outcomes of a program on individuals, communities, or systems.
  • While clinical management contributes to health outcomes, impact evaluation focuses on changes in health indicators, not the processes of service delivery.

Explanation:

PERT is a type of network analysis used in project management to model activities, dependencies, and critical paths

PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique):

  • A project management tool used to schedule, organise, and coordinate tasks within a project.
  • Particularly useful for projects with interdependent activities and uncertain durations.

Network Analysis:

  • Involves modelling and analysing relationships and dependencies among activities within a project.
  • PERT uses network diagrams (PERT charts)to visualise:
    1. Sequence of activities
    2. Dependencies between tasks
    3. Critical path- the longest path determining the minimum project duration

Helps project managers optimise schedules, allocate resources efficiently, and manage project risks.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cost-effective analysis (Option A):

  • Compares costs and outcomes of alternative actions to determine the most economical approach.
  • PERT focuses on scheduling and managing tasks, not directly on cost-effectiveness.

Cost-benefit analysis (Option B):

  • Evaluates the monetary costs and benefits of a project or decision.
  • PERT may indirectly influence costs via scheduling, but does not quantify or compare costs and benefits directly.

Work sampling (Option D):

  • Estimates the proportion of time spent on different activities in a work environment.
  • Focuses on workload distribution, productivity, and process improvement, not project scheduling.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about Six Sigma?
a. Developed by Motorola
b. Represents an ideology that focuses on statistical improvement to a business process
c. It is a quality control program
d. Can be used in the healthcare sector
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Options a, b, c, and d accurately describe Six Sigma. It was developed by Motorola, focuses on statistical improvement, serves as a quality management program, and is applicable in healthcare.

a. Developed by Motorola:

  • Six Sigma was developed by Motorola in the mid-1980sas a quality improvement methodology aimed at reducing defects and variation in manufacturing processes.
  • Motorola engineer Bill Smithis credited with creating the Six Sigma concept.

b. Represents an ideology that focuses on statistical improvement to a business process:

  • Rooted in statistical principles, Six Sigma focuses on process improvement, reducing variation, and minimising defects.
  • Emphasises data-driven decision-making, rigorous measurement, and the use of statistical tools and techniquesto identify and eliminate sources of variation.

c. It is a quality control program:

  • Six Sigma is a quality management methodologyrather than a traditional quality control program.
  • Unlike quality control, which identifies and corrects defects, Six Sigma emphasises proactive process improvementto achieve consistently high-quality outputs.

d. Can be used in the healthcare sector:

  • Six Sigma principles have been applied successfully in healthcareto improve patient outcomes, streamline processes, reduce medical errors, and enhance efficiency and quality of care.
  • Helps address challenges related to patient safety, clinical workflows, resource utilisation, and operational effectiveness.
